Executives Beyond Enron Took Months To Report SalesPublished: February 11, 2002Corporate executives have found a way, without breaking the law, to delay telling the public when they sell their own companies' stock.Fifteen executives at Colgate-Palmolive combined to sell more than $40 million in Colgate stock in 2000 and waited until early last year to disclose their sales.The retiring president of Procter & Gamble's tissues-and-towel division sold $2.8 million of company stock last June but did not report the sale for more than two months.Two top executives at Tyco International sold more than $100 million in Tyco shares in late 2000 and 2001, but the sales did not become public for as long as a year. Today, Tyco shares are worth about half what they were at the time of the transactions.All these sellers, and dozens of others, have taken advantage of an 11-year-old loophole in federal securities laws that allows executives to wait as long as 13 months to disclose their sales when the buyer of their shares is the company itself. The loophole is the same one that enabled Kenneth L. Lay, the former chief executive of Enron, to sell millions of dollars of Enron shares in the months that the stock was plummeting, without filing the usual federal disclosure forms for insider sales.In the wake of Enron's collapse and new questions about Tyco's accounting methods, corporate governance experts say the rule should be changed so that investors can have a clear, prompt picture of executive stock sales.The Securities and Exchange Commission, to prevent executives from unfairly profiting from their knowledge by selling company stock shortly before releasing bad news, requires them to report any such transactions. Even when executives are not selling shares because of pending bad news, many investors consider a management team's stockholdings to be an important measure of their confidence in the company.''For the life of me, I cannot imagine why investors shouldn't know that an executive is selling large chunks of stock to the company, whatever the reason,'' said Paul Elliott, an analyst at Thomson Financial/First Call, who tracks insider trades. Study Finds That Many Large Companies Pay No TaxesPublished: October 20, 2000Goodyear, Texaco, Colgate-Palmolive, MCI WorldCom and eight other large corporations earned more than $12.2 billion in profits in 1996 through 1998, but none of them ended up owing corporate income taxes over that period, according to a study released yesterday. The group argues that the tax system favors the rich and politically connected.Corporate profits overall soared 23.5 percent during the three-year period, but corporate tax revenues grew just 7.7 percent, a disjunction that has drawn intense interest from the Treasury Department and some members of Congress who are concerned about the growing market for tax shelters and their abuse.In recent years, Congress has watered down the 1986 overhaul of the tax laws, which lowered rates and eliminated most tax shelters, and was supposed to simplify reporting. The recent changes have opened fresh opportunities for corporations to cut their taxes, the study found.''Corporate taxes are not rising along with profits because companies have found all sorts of ways to get around the reforms in the 1986 tax act,'' said Robert S. McIntyre, the director of Citizens for Tax Justice. ''Companies also have gotten a lot of help from Congress, especially in gutting the minimum tax rules.''Mr. McIntyre said that he and T. D. Coo Nguyen, the co-author, spent more than two years examining financial statements the companies sent to shareholders.All but 18 of the companies studied are on the Fortune 500 list, and the others are in the Fortune 1000. Colgate Shares Drop 16% After Reports by AnalystsPublished: September 15, 2000Shares of Colgate-Palmolive tumbled nearly 16 percent yesterday after analysts expressed doubts that the company would meet sales targets, citing the yearlong plunge in the euro.Stubbornly high petroleum prices, meanwhile, are expected to limit Colgate's ability to cut costs.In recent quarters, Colgate, the maker of America's best-selling toothpaste and dishwashing liquid, has been a bastion of strength in the consumer products industry, consistently meeting and exceeding analysts' forecasts at a time when some of its principal competitors -- including Procter & Gamble, Clorox, and Dial -- have repeatedly warned of lethargic sales. Colgate's Appeal on Tax Shelter Is RejectedPublished: March 23, 1999The Supreme Court rejected without comment today a bid by the Colgate-Palmolive Company to gain tens of millions of dollars in tax benefits through an offshore shelter devised by Merrill Lynch & Company.Merrill Lynch had set up an unusual partnership to create losses that Colgate could deduct from its taxable income. Summers, promoted a crackdown on corporate tax shelters. Faulty Repair Seen in '97 Helicopter CrashPublished: December 16, 1998A corporate helicopter that snapped apart at the tail just after takeoff in April 1997, crashing into the East River and killing a passenger, had been improperly repaired with a part that is vulnerable to metal fatigue, members of the National Transportation Safety Board said today.The part, a type of hollow rivet, has also probably been used in other aircraft in places where it might fail, officials said. One safety board member said that the Federal Aviation Administration may eventually need to require that aircraft brought in for maintenance be inspected for hollow rivets installed in inappropriate places.''This problem is probably more widespread than we can imagine,'' said the board member, John Goglia, a former aircraft mechanic who said he himself had installed many such hollow rivets as substitutes for solid ones.The fasteners, called blind rivets, resemble the heavy-duty picture hooks sold at hardware stores that can be pushed through a small hole, expanded behind the wall and pulled snug without the installer's having access to the other side. Blind rivets can hasten aircraft repairs because they do not require mechanics to remove internal parts to get access to the inside.Mechanics at the Colgate-Palmolive Company, the owner of the helicopter that crashed in New York, installed the blind rivets in December 1992 when they replaced a part of the tail that had cracked. When the tail later cracked again, leading to the 1997 crash, the rivets were partly to blame, investigators say.A Federal Aviation Administration advisory document, which was cited by safety board members meeting today to discuss their staff's findings in the East River crash, says blind rivets can be used with the approval of the aircraft or rivet manufacturer. But Les Dorr Jr., an F.A.A. spokesman, said that the wording of the document ''could be confusing'' and that the aviation administration did not mean for mechanics to rely solely on the rivet manufacturer's advice.At the safety board's meeting, Mr. Goglia displayed a technical document from Textron Inc., the manufacturer of the rivets used on the Colgate-Palmolive helicopter, saying that blind rivets could be used to replace solid rivets. But other Textron documents noted that while blind rivets are as strong as solid ones in resisting shearing or stretching, they are less able to withstand repeated bending, which is exactly the stress they were subject to on the helicopter's tail.

Tough Tactics In One Battle Over Animals In the LabPublished: March 24, 1998ALAN STAPLE, the president of a New Jersey company that conducts animal tests for other companies, was attending a conference in England last May when he was jolted awake by a telephone call at 3 A.M. from his company's vice president.There was a corporate emergency, the company officer said. Craig Butler Tate, 51, Executive For Colgate-Palmolive CompanyPublished: April 17, 1997Craig B. Short Trip Home From Plant Ends in Tragedy for ExecutivePublished: April 16, 1997Craig B. Tate, the executive who died yesterday in the crash of a Colgate-Palmolive Company helicopter, was a driven corporate man who climbed the company ladder and an equally driven family man who enjoyed barbecues and pool parties with his family, neighbors in Connecticut said last night.Mr. Tate, who was pronounced dead of cardiac arrest upon arrival at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, was pulled from the wrecked helicopter in the murk of the East River together with James M. Executive Dies and 3 Are Hurt in an East River Copter CrashPublished: April 16, 1997A corporate executive was killed and three other people were injured when their helicopter crashed into the East River moments after lifting off from the heliport at 60th Street in Manhattan.Witnesses said the helicopter plunged into the river about 15 feet from shore after the rear rotor flew off the aircraft and lodged in the heliport's one-story terminal. Tax Court Rejects 'Phantom Loss' by ColgatePublished: March 07, 1997The Federal Tax Court has rejected as a sham an elaborate maneuver devised by Merrill Lynch & Company that had enabled the Colgate-Palmolive Company to avoid paying taxes on $98 million of gains it made in selling a subsidiary.The decision, issued Wednesday, dismissed as without substance the elaborate maneuvers, which involved a partnership that allocated capital gains largely to one partner -- a foreign bank not subject to American tax -- and capital losses to Colgate, which used the losses to offset the capital gains on the sale of a subsidiary.The case had attracted attention because it involved a clever stream of transactions that seemed to fit within the tax laws, and because Merrill, at the trial before the tax court, was forced to disclose that it had put together similar deals for such companies as Allied Signal, American Home Products, Borden, Dun & Bradstreet and Schering-Plough. At least some of those transactions have also been challenged by the Internal Revenue Service, but Wednesday's decision was the first by a court on the issue.In the decision, the tax court ruled that it did not find any ''economic substance'' to the transactions, other than to avoid taxes. It said that Colgate was not motivated by the pursuit of an investment profit, but by a desire to avoid taxes on another transaction.''We do not suggest that a taxpayer refrain from using the tax laws to the taxpayer's advantage,'' the court said. ''In this case, however, the taxpayer desired to take advantage of a loss that was not economically inherent in the object of the sale, but which the taxpayer created artificially through the manipulation and abuse of the tax laws. A taxpayer is not entitled to recognize a phantom loss from a transaction that lacks economic substance.''Steven Surdell, a partner in the Chicago law firm of Block & Jenner, said the ruling was the first to apply sophisticated analysis of interest rate swaps and various other financial techniques, and then to use that analysis to conclude that the transaction lacked economic substance.Colgate issued a statement saying that the ruling would have no effect on its cash position or reported profits, since it involved a tax bill that had been previously paid and that Colgate was trying to recover. A Merrill Lynch spokesman declined to comment.The Colgate maneuver involved setting up a partnership, owned by it, ABN-Amro Holding N.V., a Dutch bank, and Merrill Lynch. The partnership bought some Citibank notes in 1989, then sold most of them later that year. Using a section of the tax law, it allocated only part of the cost of the notes to the ones sold, thus creating a large paper profit, most of which was allocated to ABN-Amro.Then, ABN-Amro left the partnership. The sale of the rest of the Citibank notes in later years created a large paper loss, most of which was allocated to Colgate. Colgate then applied to use that loss to recover taxes previously paid on the profit from the sale of a subsidiary. The I.R.S. rejected that move, and Colgate appealed to tax court.

Jersey City's Waterfront Showing Signs of an UpturnPublished: September 15, 1996A ROLLER-COASTER office market took the commercial revitalization of the Hudson River waterfront here from the heights of the mid-80's to the depths of the early 90's, when construction ground to a halt. But in the years since, the riverfront has slowly rebounded, rekindling interest in building at the water's edge.At the northern end of the riverfront, the Lefrak Organization of Rego Park, Queens, is gearing up to build the 17-story, 750,000-square-foot Newport Office Centre III at its 400-acre Newport Center mixed-used project. About a mile south, on Colgate-Palmolive's 20-acre Colgate Center site, once occupied by a toothpaste factory, plans are advancing for a 12-story 435,000-square-foot building.Both projects have their approvals in place and will move forward once tenants are found to sign preconstruction leases, which are needed to obtain construction financing. The Lefrak Organization said it would build after 30 percent of its building was preleased. Colgate said it would go ahead when it had a tenant for half the space.Many commercial brokers say the plans reflect the strengthening of the office market along the Hudson County portion of the waterfront in general and of Jersey City's in particular. In turn, they said, the next round of office construction is not far behind.''The waterfront has been a major growth corridor for North Jersey since 1984 and since then Jersey City has given companies a lot of justification to move there,'' said Robert P. Antonicello, president of the ACI Group, a local real estate services concern. ''It is no longer a frontier. ''In that time some 8.6 million square feet of offices were built, initially for a flow of financial services companies from Manhattan seeking larger and less expensive space. A 1.2-million-square-foot regional mall was also constructed, as were thousands of residences within the waterfront redevelopment district, which stretches for 1.7 miles along the riverfront and roughly eight blocks inland.But then the 1987 stock market crash, followed by the real estate recession, stemmed the flow of tenants, leaving the riverfront with blocks of empty space and a vacancy rate that as recent as 1992 was as high as 36 percent. Under current zoning, at least 13.4 million more square feet of offices can be built on the remaining land in the district.

POSTINGS: Tenants Sought for 2 Planned Office Buildings;In Jersey City, Some Action on the WaterfrontPublished: July 07, 1996Plans are advancing for two office buildings along Jersey City's Hudson River waterfront that, if realized, would end a five-year lull in commercial construction at the river's edge.At the 600-acre Newport mixed-use project at the northern end of the waterfront the Lefrak Organization of Rego Park, Queens, is pushing Newport Office Centre III, which would have 750,000 square feet of space in a 17-story building.The complex is now home to 1.5 million square feet of mostly occupied offices in two buildings, most in Newport Tower.At the southern end of the Jersey City waterfront, on Colgate-Palmolive's 20-acre Colgate Center tract, which once held a toothpaste factory, a parcel is being readied for 90 Hudson Street, a 12-story, 435,000-square-foot structure.It would join 101 Hudson, a 1.2 million-square foot fully leased tower.Both projects are ready to go, their developers say, except for one thing. Colgate Sees Job Cuts And Lower EarningsPublished: September 21, 1995The Colgate-Palmolive Company took Wall Street by surprise yesterday when it announced that dismal results in Mexico would lower its operating earnings by more than 30 cents a share this year and that it would cut 8.5 percent of its work force in a sweeping reorganization.The company, whose products include Colgate toothpaste, Ajax cleanser and Fab detergent, said the revamping was not related to its problems in Mexico. (CL,N)Published: February 03, 1995The Colgate-Palmolive Company reported yesterday an increase of 12.3 percent in fourth-quarter profits, with sales gains in its developing markets and pet food business offsetting declines in North America.Colgate-Palmolive, the consumer products giant based in New York, earned $137.1 million, or 91 cents a share -- 1 cent higher than analysts' expectations -- in the quarter that ended on Dec. 31, compared with $122.1 million, or 78 cents a share, in the corresponding period in 1993. Sales rose 8.5 percent, to $2 billion.Colgate-Palmolive said its Asia-Africa division posted an increase of 16 percent in sales, while sales in Latin America grew by 15 percent. In Europe the company's sales gained 13 percent, but in North America sales dropped 3 percent.In addition, the Hill's Pet Nutrition division recorded an increase of 18 percent in worldwide sales, with strong growth in both the domestic and international markets.Shares of Colgate-Palmolive rose 50 cents, to $62.375, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

COMPANY NEWS; Colgate in $1.04 Billion AcquisitionPublished: January 10, 1995Moving to reduce debt and improve its recently lowered credit rating, the American Home Products Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Kolynos toothpaste, dental floss and mouthwash businesses in South America to the Colgate-Palmolive Company for $1.04 billion.American Home Products, a health care and consumer products company, said the money would go primarily to repay debt. The company borrowed most of the $9.7 billion it paid to acquire American Cyanamid last year, and analysts said American Home might try to cut debt further by selling other businesses.The oral health business, primarily under the Kolynos trademark, is entirely overseas. It had sales of about $290 million in 1994, mainly in Brazil, as well as Argentina, Colombia, Peru and Uruguay. The deal also includes oral health lines in Hungary, Greece and Taiwan.Analysts said the sale made sense for both sides. "It looks like they are getting a good price, more than three times sales and at least 20 times earnings," said David Lippman, a pharmaceutical analyst at Prudential Securities.Brenda Lee Landry, a consumer products analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company, said the deal "sounds terrific" for Colgate Palmolive, which is based in New York. She said Colgate's share of the Latin American oral care market would soar to 79 percent from 54 percent, far ahead of Unilever, with about 11 percent, and Proctor & Gamble, about 4 percent.Worldwide demand for toothpaste is growing by 5.8 percent, she said, and it is a very profitable product for Colgate-Palmolive, which already has 16 percent operating profit margins in Latin America. She estimated Colgate-Palmolive had $7.55 billion in 1994 sales.American Home Products, based in Madison, N.J., said it would keep a "significant presence in South America" as a producer of prescription and over-the-counter drugs and agricultural weed- and pest-killers. Its products include Advil and Anacin analgesics; Premarin, an estrogen replacement drug; Norplant contraceptives, and infant formula. The company will have $12.6 billion in annual sales following the American Cyanamid merger.Standard & Poor's had lowered its credit rating for American Home Products from triple-A to A-minus in September after the purchase of American Cyanamid. David Lugg, a pharmaceutical analyst at S.& P., said yesterday that reducing the debt would be "a positive, but not enough to change the American Home's credit rating."Also yesterday, Moody's Investors Service said it was reviewing Colgate's credit rating for a possible downgrade.Neil B. Sweig, a health care analyst at Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company, said yesterday's agreement was "a wonderful price." To pare its debt further, he said, American Home Products might consider selling its food business, "a good cash cow" that includes Chef Boy-ArDee pasta and Gulden's mustard; some medical device lines, or portions of American Cyanamid's medical products business. A spokesman for American Home said the company had no comment on its plans.On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, American Home Products fell 50 cents, to $63.25 a share, and Colgate-Palmolive fell 25 cents, to $59.75.

COMPANY NEWS; NO PLAN FOR REVAMPING, COLGATE-PALMOLIVE SAYSPublished: September 07, 1994The Colgate-Palmolive Company said yesterday that it had no current plans for a restructuring. The company was responding to a report last week that it would undertake a $100 million reorganization that would eliminate up to 3,000 jobs. The report was issued Thursday evening by Bloomberg Business News, and Colgate's offices in New York were closed Friday through Monday. Reuben Mark, the company's chief executive, said in a statement, "Colgate is always looking for ways to increase productivity, to streamline operations worldwide and increase value to shareholders." Colgate stock closed yesterday at $56.625, down 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. Heather Hay, an analyst who follows Colgate for J. P. Morgan Securities, said, "My sense is that they are probably mulling something over but haven't come to a decision."

COMPANY NEWS; Colgate May Eliminate Up to 3,000 PositionsPublished: September 03, 1994The Colgate-Palmolive Company will reportedly undertake a $100 million restructuring soon that would eliminate up to 3,000 jobs.Colgate-Palmolive had no response to the report, issued Thursday evening by Bloomberg Business News. Its New York headquarters offices were closed yesterday, until Tuesday.The report was based on the statement of an unnamed "management consultant who was familiar with the situation." Yesterday some equity analysts said that based on their conversations with Colgate-Palmolive executives, they thought a restructuring was possible soon. If it occurs, it would be the third in the last 10 years.According to Bloomberg, the consolidation or closing of some North American plants, as well as of some European businesses, was possible. Stock Down 75 CentsColgate stock closed yesterday at $56.75, down 75 cents on the New York Stock Exchange."I'm surprised that the stock is down," said Heather Hay, an analyst who follows Colgate for J. P. Morgan Securities. A restructuring, she said, "would help the company, since it needs to improve the profitability of its United States businesses."A factor indicating that a restructuring is possible is the track record of the company's chief executive, Reuben Mark, "who is very focused on efficiency and is an advocate of restructuring," Ms. Hay said.Walter Beach, an analyst who follows Colgate for Widmann, Siff & Company of Bryn Mawr, Pa., said that a restructuring would be "a very positive event.""They might change the structure to be more reactive," he said. "The detergent business is the weak spot in their domestic operations." Wall Street SurprisedThe company surprised Wall Street in July by reporting disappointing second-quarter revenues in its North American consumer-product business. Overall earnings increased 4 percent, to $147.7 million, or 97 cents a share, from $142.4 million, or 86 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.Colgate North America reported 9 percent lower volume in its consumer-products units and said that sales of its Colgate products had been flat for the last six months.Wall Street was expecting earnings of 99 cents a share, said Constance M. Maneaty, an analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company. "The bottom line," she said, "is that the international business in developing markets is doing well, business in Europe is rebounding, but in the United States it's under pressure."Deepak D. Raj, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, said a restructuring "would not be surprising, given recent results."

COMPANY NEWS; COLGATE BUYS ORAL HYGIENE BUSINESS IN INDIAPublished: August 18, 1994The Colgate-Palmolive Company said yesterday that its Indian unit would acquire the oral hygiene business of Hindustan Ciba-Geigy Ltd. for $41.7 million. Hindustan Ciba-Geigy is 40 percent owned by Ciba-Geigy A.G. of Switzerland. Under the agreement, Colgate-Palmolive (India) Ltd. will take over Hindustan Ciba-Geigy's Cibaca toothpaste and other brands, as well as the company's distribution and manufacturing arrangements. The purchase will increase Colgate's share in India's toothbrush market to more than 70 percent, analysts said.

COMPANY REPORTS; COLGATE-PALMOLIVE CO. (CL,N)Published: July 22, 1994The Colgate-Palmolive Company surprised Wall Street yesterday by reporting disappointing second-quarter revenues in its North American core consumer-products businesses yesterday, prompting an early selloff that leveled off by the end of the day.The company announced that earnings increased 4 percent, to $147.7 million, or 97 cents a share, from $142.4 million, or 86 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. It took a one-time charge of $5.2 million, or 4 cents a share, for the sale of Princess House, its crystal tableware unit, resulting in net income of $142.5 million, or 93 cents a share.Wall Street was expecting earnings of 99 cents a share, said Constance M. Maneaty, an analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company. "The bottom line," she said, "is that the international business in developing markets is doing well, business in Europe is rebounding, but in the United States it's under pressure."Colgate North-America reported 9 percent lower volume in its consumer-products units, and said that sales of its Colgate products had been flat for the last six months. The company attributed the results to inventory reductions by American retailers.Shares of Colgate-Palmolive fell as low as $49.50 in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, before rebounding to close at $50.50, down $1.75.
